title: Valuing User Preferences for Geospatial Fire Monitoring in Guatemala
author: Berenter, Jared and Morrison, Isaac and Mueller, Julie M.
quick_notes: willingness to pay, choice experiment - fire monitoring in guatemala -

title: Economic Assessment of the Use Value of Geospatial Information
author: Bernknopf, Richard and Shapiro, Carl
quick_notes: voi/bayesian - theory/framework with examples from agrochemicals, earthquake hazards, and ecosystem service markets, looking at how data expands the production possibilities frontier (pareto efficiency).  the first case study used landsat data; case study 2 was based on geographical info but not necessarily satellite; case study 3 looks at remote sensing for ecosystem service markets.

title: The Value of Remotely Sensed Information: The Case of a GRACE-Enhanced Drought Severity Index
author: Bernknopf, Richard and Brookshire, David and Kuwayama, Yusuke and Macauley, Molly and Rodell, Matthew and Thompson, Alexandra and Vail, Peter and Zaitchik, Benjamin
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory in framework - drought monitoring
societal_benefit: improvement in drought prediction and response with satellite data

title: Earth Observations Can Enable Cost-Effective Conservation of Eastern North Pacific Blue Whales: A Value of Information Analysis
author: Bernknopf, Richard and Steinkruger, Andrew and Kuwayama, Yusuke
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision - marine conservation
societal_benefit: cost reduction for vessel speed regulation

title: Monetising the Savings of Remotely Sensed Data and Information in Burn Area Emergency Response (BAER) Wildfire Assessment
author: Bernknopf, Richard and Kuwayama, Yusuke and Gibson, Reily and Blakely, Jessica and Mabee, Bethany and Clifford, T. J. and Quayle, Brad and Epting, Justin and Hardy, Terry and Goodrich, David
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision - fire response
societal_benefit: reduced cost of post-fire emergency response

title: Assessing the Value of Information for Water Quality Management in the North Sea
author: Bouma, J. A. and {van der Woerd}, H. J. and Kuik, O. J.
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory, stakeholder perception elicitation - marine water quality
societal_benefit: water quality monitoring for clarity, eutrophication, harmful algal blooms

title: The Value of Earth Observation for Marine Water Quality Management
author: Bouma, J. A. and Kuik, O. J. and {van der Woerd}, H. J. and Dekker, A. G.
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory, elicited beliefs of stakeholders - marine water quality - same as "assessing the value of information for water quality management in the north sea" and "assessing the value of earth observation for managing coral reefs: an example from the great barrier reef"
societal_benefit: improved water quality management decisions (gbr); improved early warning of habs (north sea)

title: Assessing the Value of Earth Observation for Managing Coral Reefs: An Example from the Great Barrier Reef
author: Bouma, Jetske A. and Kuik, Onno and Dekker, Arnold G.
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory, elicitation of decision maker perceptions - marine conservation, great barrier reef

title: The Value of Earth Observation for Managing the Great Barrier Reef
author: Bouma, Jetske and Kuik, Onno and Dekker, Arnold
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory, elicited decision maker perceptions of value - marine conservation, great barrier reef

title: Bayesian Framework for Assessing the Value of Scientific Space Systems: Value of Information Approach with Application to Earth Science Spacecraft
author: Brathwaite, Joy and Saleh, Joseph H.
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory, disaster early warning systems for hurricanes with respect to oil rigs
societal_benefit: improved forecasting of extreme weather events

title: Economic Potential of Oil Palm Plantation Using Remote Sensing-Based Technology in Indonesia
author: Center for Aerospace Policy Studies, National Institute of Aeronautics and Space (LAPAN), Indonesia} and Diana, Shinta Rahma and Farida, Farida and {Faculty of Economics and Bussiness, UPI, YAI, Indonesia
quick_notes: statistical methods to tease out effects of remote sensing to improve management efficiency (fertilization) in oil palm production

title: Value of Information for Climate Observing Systems
author: Cooke, Roger and Wielicki, Bruce A. and Young, David F. and Mlynczak, Martin G.
quick_notes: modeling link between improved climate observations, decision-making trigger status, and resulting reductions in climate damage
societal_benefit: earlier switch to reduced carbon emissions path

title: Market-Based Methods for Monetizing Uncertainty Reduction
author: Cooke, Roger and Golub, Alexander
quick_notes: options pricing to assess voi/bayesian, based on improved accuracy of weather forecasting

title: Cost and Value of Multidisciplinary Fixed-Point Ocean Observatories
author: Cristini, Luisa and Lampitt, Richard S. and Cardin, Vanessa and Delory, Eric and Haugan, Peter and O'Neill, Nick and Petihakis, George and Ruhl, Henry A.
quick_notes: cost-benefit analysis? highlights challenges in accurately quantifying economic value of ocean observations - fairly surface level analysis.  ocean-based observation, not satellite

title: An Analysis of the Value of Additional Information Provided by a Water Quality Measurement Network
author: Destandau, F. and Diop, A. P.
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory - economic benefit of improved decision in water quality measurement network

title: Intangible Economic Benefit of Remote Sensing Data in Indonesia
author: Diana, Shinta Rahma and Ibrahim, Ida Musdafia
quick_notes: qualitative techniques, questionnaire and in-depth interviews

title: A Conceptual Framework for Assessing the Benefits of a Global Earth Observation System of Systems
author: Fritz, S. and Scholes, R.J. and Obersteiner, M. and Bouma, J. and Reyers, B.
quick_notes: benefit chain concept - causal pathway from incremental improvements in the observing system (cost = investment cost for marginal increase in eo effort) to better management and outcomes (benefit = marginal increase in societal benefits given a marginal increase in effort) - marginal cost-benefit ratio, i.e., shape of a logistic benefit-cost curve, max incremental benefit:cost is where the slope is steepest
societal_benefit: many (case studies: fire control due to better weather forecasts, improved data for conservation planning; marine water quality monitoring)

title: Pricing Policy and Legal Issues: 6th and 7th EOPOLE Workshops
author: Harris, Ray and Olby, Nicola
quick_notes: pricing policy of earth observation data, linear regression of log(price per km2) as a function of log(pixel size)

title: Earth Observation and the Public Good
author: Harris, Ray and Miller, Lewis
quick_notes: public goods theory; framework of thinking about satellite data in terms of rivalry and excludability, with nine eo missions placed in various locations on this plane.  not technically valuing the data, but ranking them relatively along the two axes?

title: A Method for Estimating the Socioeconomic Impact of Earth Observations in Wildland Fire Suppression Decisions
author: Herr, Vincent and Kochanski, Adam K. and Miller, Van V. and McCrea, Rich and O'Brien, Dan and Mandel, Jan
quick_notes: hypothetical scenarios of fire suppression decisions with and without modis data.  sounds like voi/bayesian as done through simulations
societal_benefit: reduced losses from wildfire due to improved firebreak decisions

title: Agricultural Producers' Willingness to Pay for Real-Time Mesoscale Weather Information
author: Kenkel, Phil L. and Norris, Patricia E.
quick_notes: contingent valuation - survey of farmers and ranchers on willingness to pay for improved weather information.  includes both raw weather data and value-added information products.  not satellite data but still seems like remote observation can apply

title: Valuing Weather Observation Systems For Forest Fire Management
author: Khabarov, N. and Moltchanova, E. and Obersteiner, M.
quick_notes: voi/bayesian based on reduction in burned areas based on either coarse or fine resolution weather data.  not satellite data - aerial patrols - but can be generalized

title: Valuing Geospatial Information: Using the Contingent Valuation Method to Estimate the Economic Benefits of Landsat Satellite Imagery
author: Loomis, John and Koontz, Steve and Miller, Holly and Richardson, Leslie
quick_notes: contingent valuation survey of landsat users - established and new users.  societal benefit - looks at economic losses associated with charging for use, based on modeled demand curve

title: The Value of Information: Measuring the Contribution of Space-Derived Earth Science Data to Resource Management
author: Macauley, Molly K.
quick_notes: might be a review; sounds like overview of various methods incl econometrics, hedonic pricing, contingent valuation, and looks at case studies

title: Using Architecture Modeling to Assess the Societal Benefits of the Global Earth Observation System-of-Systems
author: Martin, J.N.
quick_notes: ‚Äúenterprise architecture modeling‚Äù? various contexts - fig. 3 assigns "high" "medium" and "low" importance (value?) of certain types of earth observations to benefit areas that closely map onto the current nasa applied science themes.

title: Banda Aceh-The Value of Earth Observation Data in Disaster Recovery and Reconstruction: A Case Study
author: McCallum, I. and Kidd, R. and Fritz, S. and Kraxner, F. and Obersteiner, M. and Shvidenko, Anatoly
quick_notes: questionnaire - contingent value? cost-benefit for bathymetry, photo vs traditional surveying/mapping - context of disaster relief in banda aceh
societal_benefit: improvement in data for improved disaster response

title: Integrating Earth Observation Data into Geospatial Databases That Support Public Health Decisions
author: Morain, S. A. and Budge, A. M.
quick_notes: dust forecasting - compares model outputs using higher-resolution eo data to see how model performs? no valuation of information except for model performance
societal_benefit: improved dust forecasting for health care

title: Visual Evidence from Above: Assessing the Value of Earth Observation Satellites for Supporting Human Rights
author: Notley, Tanya and {Webb-Gannon}, Camellia
quick_notes: qualitative research approach - critical analysis, interviews, case studies of satellite images in human rights contexts.  doesn't quite "measure" the value, but connects specific aspects of justice to eo data

title: The Value of Near Real-Time Earth Observations for Improved Flood Disaster Response
author: Oddo, Perry C. and Bolten, John D.
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory - for emergency response vehicle routing.

title: What Is the Economic Value of Satellite Imagery?
author: Raunikar, Ronald P. and Forney, William M. and Benjamin, Susan P.
quick_notes: voi/bayesian decision theory - agricultural production and groundwater quality via nitrate loading, with and without high-quality info from satellite imagery
societal_benefit: avoided nitrate pollution of groundwater; improved crop value

title: A PROFESSIONAL REVIEW FOR INTEGRATION OF EARTH OBSERVATIONS INTO FEWS NET DECISION SUPPORT
author: Ross, Kenton W. and Underwood, Lauren W. and Brown, Molly E.
quick_notes: survey of experts - ‚Äúprofessional review questionnaire‚Äù - to elicit user requirements and importance of certain data types for famine early warning (fews net)

title: Impact of Global Earth Observation - Systemic View across GEOSS Societal Benefit Areas
author: Rydzak, Felicjan and Obersteiner, Michael and Kraxner, Florian
quick_notes: felix model is system dynamics model that captures how changes in one area affects other areas, e.g., feedback loops, delays, nonlinear relationships. baseline scenario to compare impact of improvements in geoss across different societal benefit areas

title: Geographic Microtargeting of Social Assistance with High-Resolution Poverty Maps
author: Smythe, Isabella S. and Blumenstock, Joshua E.
quick_notes: compares performance of ml/eo based maps survey-based maps for targeting poverty alleviation in nigeria

title: A Benefit-Cost Analysis of a Regional Global Ocean Observing System: Seawatch Europe
author: Stel, Jan H and Mannix, Brian F
quick_notes: not satellite, bu network of global ocean observing system - cost-benefit analysis, societal benefits relative to cost.  estimates benefits in marine structural design, oil/gas exploration, commercial fisheries, aquaculture, tourism, crisis response, etc.

title: Using Satellite Data to Fill the Gaps in the US Air Pollution Monitoring Network
author: Sullivan, Daniel M and Krupnick, Alan
quick_notes: satellite data vs. official determinations of attainment of pm2.5 standards - difference in difference design, estimates impact of misclassification or premature deaths

title: The Socio-Economic Value of Satellite Earth Observations: Huge, yet to Be Measured
author: Tassa, Alessandra
quick_notes: value chain analysis - a framework or general set of methodologies, does not apply the framework but describes the basics

title: On-Going European Space Agency Activities on Measuring the Benefits of Earth Observations to Society: Challenges, Achievements and Next Steps
author: Tassa, Alessandra and Willekens, Stephanie and Lahcen, Arne and Laurich, Laurent and Mathieu, Charlotte
quick_notes: methods to estimate societal benefits - cost-benefit analysis, socioeconomic indicators; mentions case studies in agriculture, cc mitigation, disaster management, public health.

title: Potential Benefits of Coastal Ocean Observing Systems to Alaskan Commercial Fisheries
author: Wellman, Katharine F. and Hartley, Marcus

title: Benefits of the Free and Open Landsat Data Policy
author: Zhu, Zhe and Wulder, Michael A. and Roy, David P. and Woodcock, Curtis E. and Hansen, Matthew C. and Radeloff, Volker C. and Healey, Sean P. and Schaaf, Crystal and Hostert, Patrick and Strobl, Peter and Pekel, Jean-Francois and Lymburner, Leo and Pahlevan, Nima and Scambos, Ted A.
quick_notes: describes benefits of free and open access to landsat imagery - more downloads, more publications, more uptake for research; also describes economic benefits, but referring to papers elsewhere that did those analyses

title: Using Data from Earth Observation to Support Sustainable Development Indicators: An Analysis of the Literature and Challenges for the Future
author: Andries, Ana and Morse, Stephen and Murphy, Richard J. and Lynch, Jim and Woolliams, Emma R.

title: Assessing the Full Effects of Public Investment in Space
author: Clark, John and Koopmans, Carl and Hof, Bert and Knee, Paula and Lieshout, Rogier and Simmonds, Paul and Wokke, Frank
quick_notes: categorizes impacts of investment in space technology across economic, social, strategic, and environmental including spillover effects and such - a meta-analysis.  includes good summaries of various valuation methods.  proposes framework for combining results from across various impacts and such, but doesn't actually apply it.

title: An Economic Value of Remote Sensing Information: Application to Agricultural Production and Maintaining Groundwater Quality

title: The Potential Value of Improved Ocean Observation Systems in the Gulf of Mexico

author: Glantz, Michael

author: Flechsig, Michael
quick_notes: survey of individuals and managers

title: Diagnosing Irrigation Performance and Water Productivity through Satellite Remote Sensing and Secondary Data in a Large Irrigation System of Pakistan

quick_notes: uses ro data in conjunction with others to improve understanding of water consumption; this allows deeper understandings of patterns of water use equity and sustainability.  the value is in the improvement in understanding - there's no decision analyzed in the paper, but reduction in uncertainty around these values must be worth something...  do they actually quantify the improvement in uncertainty though?

title: Lake Nasser Evaporation Reduction Study
author: Ebaid, Hala M. I. and Ismail, Sherine S.
quick_notes: maybe: uses landsat for temperature data on lake, to feed into an evaporation model.  results can inform a decision to disconnect khors to reduce evaporation? but did it really depend on the landsat data?

title: Combining Passive Acoustics and Environmental Data for Scaling up Ecosystem Monitoring: A Test on Coral Reef Fishes
author: Elise, Simon and Guilhaumon, Francois and {Mou-Tham}, Gerard and {Urbina-Barreto}, Isabel and Vigliola, Laurent and Kulbicki, Michel and Bruggemann, J. Henrich
quick_notes: passive acoustic, not satellite or anything? combines visual surveys with passive acoustic surveys to predict fish assemblage structures.  "globally, the acoustic data showed relatiely low added value in predicting fish assemblage structures."  does not explicitly value in terms of societal benefits though
notes: looks like a cool study - includes functional entities?

title: Competition and Burn Severity Determine Post-Fire Sapling Recovery in a Nationally Protected Boreal Forest of China: An Analysis from Very High-Resolution Satellite Imagery
author: Fang, L. and Crocker, E. V. and Yang, J. and Yan, Y. and Yang, Y. and Liu, Z.
quick_notes: maybe: compares 30m landsat to 0.5m worldview-2 imagery, based on field sampling data.  they qualitatively compare performance and show that vhr data outperforms moderate res data; but is more costly currently.  societal benefit: monitoring recovery from wildfires, informing management?  they don't quantify the benefit

title: Integrating Drone Imagery with Existing Rangeland Monitoring Programs
author: Gillan, J. K. and Karl, J. W. and {van Leeuwen}, W. J. D.
quick_notes: does not calculate a quantified value, shows that uav imagery can do a good job of classifying vegetation  type and height (for most veg types), toward "assessment, inventory, and monitoring" for rangeland management.  but when answering "is drone monitoring worth the effort?", responds no, it will not replace most of the field methods, but can be complementary.

title: The Value of Site-Specific Information and the Environment: Technology Adoption and Pesticide Use under Uncertainty
author: Isik, M and Hudson, D and Coble, {\relax KH

title: An Evaluation of Public Servant Awareness and Use of Gis/Remote Sensing in Africa-Nigeria
author: Asiyanbola, Raimi Abidemi
quick_notes: Survey of Nigerian public servants - "Table 3 shows that most of the respondents were aware of the direct benefits of GIS/remote sensing such as increased effectiveness (faster provision of information, [65%], information more readily available [65%], up-to-date information available [58%]), savings (less space required for, e.g., map storage [67%], time savings for routine and repetitive tasks [56%]) and new products (new range of output ñ maps, tables, etc. [36%], better quality output [55%]). Also, most of the respondents were aware of the indirect benefits of GIS/remote sensing such as justification for the decision made (59%), better-informed decision making (55%), and greater analysis and understanding of problems (51%). Generally, the results shows that respondents were more aware of the direct benefits of GIS/remote sensing (53%) compared to their awareness of the indirect benefits (45%)."
notes: Costs/benefits, also diffusion of knowledge/practice of GIS/remote sensing in Nigerian public sector

quick_notes: "This exploratory research found that a Google Earth ëvirtual globeí tour can be a valuable tool in the initial stages of an NFM project, but there are also opportunities to use this technique in the more advanced stages of the planning process."
